description: Ubuntu 22.04 LTS CIS Benchmark - Section 3.3 Configure Network Kernel Parameters

controls.title: Ensure net.ipv4.ip_forward is configured
controls.description: The net.ipv4.ip_forward flag is used to tell the system whether it can forward packets or not.
controls.rationale: Setting the flag to 0 ensures that a system with multiple interfaces (for example, a hard proxy), will never be able to forward packets, and therefore, never serve as a router.
controls.impact: Setting this parameter to 0 will disable IP forwarding and may break systems that require this functionality.
controls.remediation: Set the following parameter in /etc/sysctl.conf or a /etc/sysctl.d/* file: net.ipv4.ip_forward = 0 and run the following command to set the active kernel parameter: sysctl -w net.ipv4.ip_forward=0

controls.title: Ensure net.ipv4.conf.all.send_redirects is configured
controls.description: ICMP Redirects are used to send routing information to other hosts. As a host itself does not act as a router (in a host only configuration), there is no need to send redirects.
controls.rationale: An attacker could use a compromised host to send invalid ICMP redirects to other router devices in an attempt to corrupt routing and have users access a system set up by the attacker as opposed to a valid system.
controls.impact: Setting this parameter to 0 will disable ICMP redirect sending.
controls.remediation: Set the following parameter in /etc/sysctl.conf or a /etc/sysctl.d/* file: net.ipv4.conf.all.send_redirects = 0 and run the following command to set the active kernel parameter: sysctl -w net.ipv4.conf.all.send_redirects=0

controls.rationale: An attacker could use a compromised host to send invalid ICMP redirects to other router devices in an attempt to corrupt routing and have users access a system set up by the attacker as opposed to a valid system.
controls.impact: Setting this parameter to 0 will disable ICMP redirect sending.
controls.remediation: Set the following parameter in /etc/sysctl.conf or a /etc/sysctl.d/* file: net.ipv4.conf.default.send_redirects = 0 and run the following command to set the active kernel parameter: sysctl -w net.ipv4.conf.default.send_redirects=0

controls.title: Ensure net.ipv4.icmp_ignore_bogus_error_responses is configured
controls.description: Setting icmp_ignore_bogus_error_responses to 1 prevents the kernel from logging bogus responses (RFC-1122 non-compliant) from broadcast reframes, keeping file systems from filling up with useless log messages.
controls.rationale: Some routers (and some attackers) will send responses that violate RFC-1122 and attempt to fill up a log file system with many useless error messages.
controls.impact: Setting this parameter to 1 will ignore bogus ICMP error responses.
controls.remediation: Set the following parameter in /etc/sysctl.conf or a /etc/sysctl.d/* file: net.ipv4.icmp_ignore_bogus_error_responses = 1 and run the following command to set the active kernel parameter: sysctl -w net.ipv4.icmp_ignore_bogus_error_responses=1

controls.title: Ensure net.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts is configured
controls.description: Setting net.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts to 1 will cause the system to ignore all ICMP ECHO and TIMESTAMP requests sent to it via broadcast/multicast.
controls.rationale: Accepting ICMP echo and timestamp requests with broadcast or multicast destinations for your network could be used to probe or attack your network.
controls.impact: Setting this parameter to 1 will ignore broadcast ICMP requests.
controls.remediation: Set the following parameter in /etc/sysctl.conf or a /etc/sysctl.d/* file: net.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts = 1 and run the following command to set the active kernel parameter: sysctl -w net.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts=1

controls.title: Ensure net.ipv4.conf.all.accept_redirects is configured
controls.description: ICMP redirect messages are packets that convey routing information and tell your host (acting as a router) to send packets via an alternate path.
controls.rationale: Attackers could use bogus ICMP redirect messages to maliciously alter the system routing tables and get them to send packets to incorrect networks and allow your system packets to be captured.
controls.impact: Setting this parameter to 0 will disable ICMP redirect acceptance.
controls.remediation: Set the following parameter in /etc/sysctl.conf or a /etc/sysctl.d/* file: net.ipv4.conf.all.accept_redirects = 0 and run the following command to set the active kernel parameter: sysctl -w net.ipv4.conf.all.accept_redirects=0

controls.title: Ensure net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_redirects is configured
controls.description: ICMP redirect messages are packets that convey routing information and tell your host (acting as a router) to send packets via an alternate path.
controls.rationale: Attackers could use bogus ICMP redirect messages to maliciously alter the system routing tables and get them to send packets to incorrect networks and allow your system packets to be captured.

controls.remediation: Set the following parameter in /etc/sysctl.conf or a /etc/sysctl.d/* file: net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_redirects = 0 and run the following command to set the active kernel parameter: sysctl -w net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_redirects=0

controls.title: Ensure net.ipv4.conf.all.secure_redirects is configured
controls.description: Secure ICMP redirects are the same as ICMP redirects, except they come from gateways listed on the default gateway list.
controls.rationale: It is still possible for even known gateways to be compromised. Setting net.ipv4.conf.all.secure_redirects to 0 protects the system from routing table updates by possibly compromised known gateways.
controls.impact: Setting this parameter to 0 will disable secure ICMP redirect acceptance.
controls.remediation: Set the following parameter in /etc/sysctl.conf or a /etc/sysctl.d/* file: net.ipv4.conf.all.secure_redirects = 0 and run the following command to set the active kernel parameter: sysctl -w net.ipv4.conf.all.secure_redirects=0

controls.title: Ensure net.ipv4.conf.all.rp_filter is configured
controls.description: Setting net.ipv4.conf.all.rp_filter and net.ipv4.conf.default.rp_filter to 1 forces the Linux kernel to utilize reverse path filtering on a received packet to determine if the packet was valid.
controls.rationale: Setting these flags is a good way to deter attackers from sending your system bogus packets that cannot be responded to. One instance where this feature breaks down is if asymmetrical routing is employed. This would occur when using dynamic routing protocols (bgp, ospf, etc) on your system. If you are using asymmetrical routing on your system, you will not be able to enable this feature without breaking the routing.
controls.impact: Setting this parameter to 1 will enable reverse path filtering.
controls.remediation: Set the following parameter in /etc/sysctl.conf or a /etc/sysctl.d/* file: net.ipv4.conf.all.rp_filter = 1 and run the following command to set the active kernel parameter: sysctl -w net.ipv4.conf.all.rp_filter=1

controls.title: Ensure net.ipv4.conf.all.accept_source_route is configured
controls.description: In networking, source routing allows a sender to partially or fully specify the route packets take through a network.
controls.rationale: Setting net.ipv4.conf.all.accept_source_route and net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_source_route to 0 disables the system from accepting source routed packets. Assume this system was capable of routing packets to Internet routers. If attackers were able to send source routed packets through the system, they could be able to probe your internal network, bypass firewalls, and have their traffic routed back to them.
controls.impact: Setting this parameter to 0 will disable source routing acceptance.
controls.remediation: Set the following parameter in /etc/sysctl.conf or a /etc/sysctl.d/* file: net.ipv4.conf.all.accept_source_route = 0 and run the following command to set the active kernel parameter: sysctl -w net.ipv4.conf.all.accept_source_route=0

controls.title: Ensure net.ipv4.conf.all.log_martians is configured
controls.description: The net.ipv4.conf.all.log_martians parameter logs packets with impossible addresses to the kernel log.
controls.rationale: Enabling this feature and logging these packets allows an administrator to investigate the possibility that an attacker is sending spoofed packets to their system.
controls.impact: Setting this parameter to 1 will enable logging of martian packets.
controls.remediation: Set the following parameter in /etc/sysctl.conf or a /etc/sysctl.d/* file: net.ipv4.conf.all.log_martians = 1 and run the following command to set the active kernel parameter: sysctl -w net.ipv4.conf.all.log_martians=1

controls.title: Ensure net.ipv4.tcp_syncookies is configured
controls.description: When tcp_syncookies is set, the kernel will handle TCP SYN packets normally until the half-open connection queue is full, at which time, the kernel will begin dropping SYN packets from the queue. The kernel will also begin to send SYN+ACK packets with a cookie value appended to the TCP sequence number field.
controls.rationale: Attackers use SYN flood attacks to perform a denial of service attacked on a system by sending many SYN packets without completing the three way handshake. This will quickly use up slots in the kernel's half-open connection queue and prevent legitimate connections from succeeding. SYN cookies allow the system to keep accepting valid connections, even if under a denial of service attack.
controls.impact: Setting this parameter to 1 will enable TCP SYN cookies.
controls.remediation: Set the following parameter in /etc/sysctl.conf or a /etc/sysctl.d/* file: net.ipv4.tcp_syncookies = 1 and run the following command to set the active kernel parameter: sysctl -w net.ipv4.tcp_syncookies=1

controls.title: Ensure net.ipv6.conf.all.accept_ra is configured
controls.description: This setting defines how the system processes router advertisements.
controls.rationale: It is recommended that systems not accept router advertisements as they could be tricked into routing traffic to compromised machines. Setting hard routes within the system (usually a single default route to a trusted router) protects the system from bad routes.
controls.impact: Setting this parameter to 0 will disable IPv6 router advertisement acceptance.
controls.remediation: Set the following parameter in /etc/sysctl.conf or a /etc/sysctl.d/* file: net.ipv6.conf.all.accept_ra = 0 and run the following command to set the active kernel parameter: sysctl -w net.ipv6.conf.all.accept_ra=0
